A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
Does the concept of a/an Map/Function need to be defined for a definition of a/an Image of Map to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand the concept of the 'Image of a Map,' it is essential to first comprehend what a 'Map' or 'Function' is. The definition of 'Image of a Map' explicitly refers to a function 'f: A to B,' indicating a relationship where elements of set A are associated with elements of set B. Without understanding this relationship, the concept of an image, which involves elements of B that are associated with at least one element in A via the function, cannot be fully grasped. Therefore, the definition of a Map/Function is fundamental to making sense of what an Image of a Map is, as it lays the groundwork for understanding how elements are related and associated between two sets.
